title: 112_s1274
content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" may be cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes key actions such as the President submitting his budget by the first Monday in February, the Budget Committees reporting a concurrent resolution on the budget by April 1, and Congress completing action on reconciliation legislation by June 15. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15, House completes action on appropriation bills by June 30, and Congress completes action on appropriation bills by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, special dates apply if a new President's term begins. The first session of Congress following a leap year has specific deadlines for budget-related actions, including the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in April, committees submitting views and estimates by April 20, and Congress completing action on the biennial budget by June 1. Biennial appropriation bills may be considered in the House by July 1. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriations bills and reconciliation legislation. The biennium begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Transportation, HUD, Interior, Environment, Labor, HHS, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Financial Services, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. Amendments to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 are proposed. Amendments to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 include defining "biennium" as a 2-year period starting on October 1 and adjusting committee allocations for appropriations over the biennium and defense. Amendments to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 define a "biennium" as a 2-year period starting on October 1 and adjust committee allocations for appropriations over the biennium and defense. The amendments also specify budget resolutions for defense and each fiscal year in the biennium, as well as the total of all fiscal years covered by the resolution. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including specifying each fiscal year in the biennium for which the budget is submitted and the following 4 years. Section 1105 of title 31 is amended to update references to fiscal years and bienniums. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve updating references to prior year outlays and receipts by specifying the 2 most recently completed fiscal years instead of just the prior fiscal year. The changes aim to provide a more accurate representation of financial data for the specified fiscal years. Additionally, Section 1105(e)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to adjust the language regarding capital investment analysis for the biennium budget. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the style and title of Acts making appropriations for the support of the Government, including defense appropriations. All Acts must indicate the amount of appropriations provided for each fiscal year. The style and title of Acts making appropriations for the Government, including defense appropriations, must indicate the amount of appropriations provided for each fiscal year in the specified biennium. Definitions for terms like 'biennium' are provided in related Congressional Budget Acts. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Amends Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include new section on authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate, unless no further appropriations are needed. It also restricts certain bills in odd-numbered years until Congress completes budget resolution and appropriations bills. In the Senate, this does not apply to defense or privileged measures. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate, unless no further appropriations are needed. It also restricts certain bills in odd-numbered years until Congress completes budget resolution and appropriations bills. In the Senate, this does not apply to defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, or appropriations measures/reconciliation bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings on agency activities not funded under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The hearing reviews the agency's mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also mentioned. The Director of OMB will study the impact of changing the fiscal year to a 2-year period with a biennial budget process and report findings to Congress. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2013, applying to budget resolutions starting from fiscal year 2014.
